1. 

Background 

The Project forms part of the Bangkok-Phnom Penh-Ho Chi Minh City-Vung Tau Road 
2. 
Improvement Project (Greater Mekong Subregion [GMS] Regional Highway R1), which is one of 
10  high-priority  subregional  road  projects  identified  in  a  Subregional  Transport  Sector  Study 
completed in 1994.1 The GMS R1 forms the core of the Southern Economic Corridor that links 
central Thailand, Cambodia, and southern Viet Nam. The GMS R1 project was endorsed by the 
Fourth  GMS  Ministerial  Conference  in  1994  and  reaffirmed  at  the  10th  GMS  Ministerial 
Conference  in  November  2001.  The  Project  will  rehabilitate  a  50-kilometer  (km)  section  of 
national road (NR) 5, thereby completing the Bangkok-Phnom Penh-Ho Chi Minh City-Vung Tau 
GMS R1, which together with ongoing and planned improvements along NR1 between Phnom 
Penh  and  Ho  Chi  Minh  City,  and  improvement  and  bridge  replacement  on  NR5  and  NR6 
financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  Government  of  Japan,  and  the  World 
Bank, will complete the southern leg of the Southern Economic Corridor.2 At the national level, 
the  Project  responds  to  the  Government’s  infrastructure  development  emphasis  on  improving 
the national and provincial road network to allow more effective access to the rural areas and 
induce  economic  growth.  The  roads  covered  by  the  Project  lie  in  the  northwestern  part  of  the 
country  and  include  important  strategic  and  rural  access  links  that  address  trade  and  poverty 
reduction  issues.  Northwestern  Cambodia  is  one  of  the  poorest  regions  of  the  country  and 
critically needs postconflict reconstruction to enable resumption of economic activities. It is also 
the region containing Angkor Wat, which forms the basis for a rapidly growing tourism industry, 
and  is  the  entry  and  exit  point  for  most  of  the  trade  between  Cambodia  and  Thailand.  The 
Project Framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
3.

and social development of the country, despite the fact that much has been achieved in terms of 
rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  of  the  transport  system  during  the  past  10  years.  Notably,  a 
core network of national roads, comprising approximately one third of the primary road network, 
has  been  reestablished,  with  support  from  ADB  and  other  development  partners.  A  list  of 
external  assistance  activities  for  major  roads  is  in  Appendix  2.  The  main  seaport  at 
Sihanoukville,  and  the  airports  at  Phnom  Penh  and  Siem  Reap,  have  also  been  rehabilitated

2. 

Road Network 

The  Cambodian  road  network  covers  about  35,500  km,  including  approximately 
4. 
4,000 km of national roads, 3,500 km of provincial roads, and 28,000 km of rural and strategic 
roads. The roads have a significant number of bridges, about 4,000 on the primary roads alone. 
Most  of  the  road  network  is  dilapidated  and  large  parts  of  the  country  are  effectively  isolated 
during  the  wet  season.  Most  bridges  are  seriously  damaged  or  failed.  The  Ministry  of  Public 
Works  and  Transport  (MPWT)  considers  that  at  least  half  of  the  primary  road  network  and 
nearly  all  of  the  secondary  and  tertiary  roads  are  in  need  of  urgent  repair,  rehabilitation,  or 
reconstruction. Road condition surveys in 2002 confirm that 28% of the network is in good or fair 
condition,  35%  in  poor  condition,  28%  in  bad  condition,  and  6%  under  reconstruction  or 
rehabilitation. An assessment of the road sector is presented in Appendix 3. Road transport is 
the  dominant  mode  of  transport  within  Cambodia,  accounting  for  65%  of  all  passenger  traffic 
and 70% of all cargo traffic, with rail, river, and air transport sharing the rest. Subregional traffic 
is  dominated  by  road  and  river  modes  catering  to  cargo  traffic,  and  air  and  road  transport 
catering to passenger traffic. Subregional traffic is still modest, but Cambodia and its neighbors 
are making great efforts at promoting and easing international traffic, developing effective cross-
border  agreements  to  facilitate  movement  of  goods  and  people,  adopting  uniform  navigational 
rules  on  the  Mekong  River,  and  developing  border  crossing  infrastructure  and  border  access 
roads. 
 
5.

NR5 and NR1 in Cambodia. The road section from Poipet on the Cambodia-Thailand border to 
Sisophon represents the last remaining gap on GMS Regional Highway 1 to be rehabilitated.

Government Policy for the Sector 

7. 
Under the April 2001 draft Second Five-Year Socioeconomic Development Plan 2001–
2005 (SEDP II), the policy objective of rehabilitating and maintaining transport infrastructure is 
to be achieved by giving priority to road rehabilitation and to improvements in road operations 
and  maintenance  capability.  The  Five-Year  Road  Master  Plan  (2000–2005)  has  three  main 
aims:  (i) to  rehabilitate  and  reconstruct  the  main  national  roads,  thereby  improving  land 
transport throughout the nation; (ii) to build road links to neighboring countries, thereby opening 
up some of the more remote areas of the country to international trade and tourism; and (iii) to

4. 

Poverty in Northwestern Cambodia 

The provinces of Siem Reap, Banteay Meanchey, and Oddar Meanchey in northwestern 
10. 
Cambodia, where the Project is located, have received minimal development assistance in the 
past  because  of  war  and  insecurity,  and  suffer  from  a  high  incidence  of  poverty  and 
vulnerability,  as  shown  in  a  1999  World  Food  Program  poverty  mapping  study.  Poverty  is 
widespread  in  the  area  with  severe  problems  of  accessibility  during  the  rainy  season.  This  is 
especially  evident  for  Oddar  Meanchey.  The  study  suggests  that  no  less  than  60%  of 
households suffer from food deficiency. Although there is some scope for foraging, hunting, and 
gathering to supplement precarious livelihoods, most households find their food stocks depleted 
within  4  months  of  harvest.  It  is  estimated  that  40–60%  of  households  are  below  the  official 
poverty line. Government services, such as health and education, rarely reach the interior and 
tend to be restricted to peri-urban areas. Family spacing is nonexistent and reproductive health 
services are largely inaccessible due to the widely dispersed nature of the population and long 
travel distances, especially within Oddar Meanchey. 
 
11. 
The provinces of Siem Reap, Banteay Meanchey, and Oddar Meanchey are some of the 
most  backward  in  Cambodia  in  terms  of  farming  practices,  physical  infrastructure,  and  social, 
health,  and  utility  services.  Drinking  water  is  usually  obtained  from  rainwater  stored  in  open 
depressions,  clay  pots,  or  from  bore-wells;  latrines  are  virtually  nonexistent.  Clinics  and 
hospitals  are  located  in  the  district  headquarters,  entailing  long  travel  times  and  high  costs. 
While many households have cattle for tillage and transport, motorcycles and television sets are 
very few. Generally, housing conditions are very poor, especially along NR56 and NR68 and in 
areas  further  away  from  the  main  centers.  Access  to  basic  health  and  education  services  is 
fragmentary,  owing  to  the  relative  remoteness  of  the  villages  and  populations  living  in  the 
northwestern area served by NR56 and NR68. Road conditions are extremely poor with virtually 
all  bridges  broken  or  unusable.  Owing  to  lack  of  continuous  access,  the  traffic  consists  of 
motorbikes,  animal  carts,  and  taxi-vans.  Transport  costs  are  predictably  high  as  travel  time  is 
long. 
 
12. 
The  overall  poverty  estimate  for  the  project  area  is  about  40%.  However,  there  are 
significant variations, with the areas serviced by better roads displaying the lowest poverty level 
(25%), while NR56 and areas serviced by poor roads have very high poverty levels (over 60%). 
Thus,  quite  apart  from  relatively  high  poverty  levels  in  the  project  area  compared  with  the 
national situation, there are deep pockets of extensive poverty, much of which is related to the 
relative physical remoteness and poor infrastructure in the area.

NR5 and NR6 

18. 
The  Project  will  rehabilitate  a  road  section  of  about  150 km  of  highway  and  about  45 
bridges  on  NR5  and  NR6.  NR5  and  NR6  connect  three  major  towns  in  the  area:  Siem  Reap, 
Sisophon (both provincial capitals), and Poipet (the primary border crossing between Cambodia 
and Thailand). From Poipet there is a direct highway connection to Bangkok, and from Sisophon 
and Siem Reap there are direct highway connections to Phnom Penh, running east and west of 
Tonle Sap, respectively. Siem Reap on NR6 is the center of an established and growing tourism 
industry based on Angkor Wat and many other historic temples in the area. NR6 connects Siem 
Reap  to  the  southern  part  of  Viet  Nam  through  Phnom  Penh,  while  NR5  also  links  Cambodia 
with Thailand and southern Viet Nam.  
 
19. 
The  road  traverses  primarily  agricultural  land.  Only  a  few  villages  are  located  at  the 
roadside, the majority of the population living in the hinterland along the secondary and tertiary 
road  network.  The  agricultural  potential  of  the  area  is  high,  but  presently  underutilized  due  to 
widespread  unexploded  ordnance  (UXO),  which  also  hinders  the  resettlement  of  people 
displaced  during  the  years  of  civil  strife.  The  ongoing  ADB-financed  Northwestern  Rural 
Development Project (NRDP),5 which is located in the general area of influence of the proposed 
Project, includes a significant component of rural roads rehabilitation. The rural roads all link into 
the project road, which form the spine of the local road networks and provide the connection to 
higher-growth  centers.  Full  realization  of  the  intended  benefits  from  NRDP  will  depend  on 
rehabilitation of the highways that provide access. 
 
20. 
The  current  condition  of  the  project  roads  is  very  poor,  with  most  of  the  pavements 
completely  failed  and  covered  with  graded  dirt.  These  sections  of  the  road  are  impassable 
during  the  wet  season.  The  road  has  a  large  number  of  cross-drainage  structures  (over  100 
culverts and 50 bridges) that are located mainly between Sisophon and Siem Reap. The road 
borders  the  Tonle  Sap  floodplain  and  is  crossed  by  a  large  number  of  tributaries  to  the  Tonle 
Sap.  Beyond  Sisophon  the  land  is  elevated  and  dry.  Most  bridges  were  either  severely 
damaged  or  demolished  during  the  years  of  civil  strife  and  many  have  been  replaced  with 
temporary Bailey bridges. The Bailey bridges are narrow and many are partly failed. The road 
embankment  is  significantly  deteriorated  in  some  places.  During  the  wet  season,  certain 
sections are often inundated. 
 
21. 
Present traffic on the project road consists primarily of pedestrians, cycles, motorcycles, 
cars  and  pickups,  trucks  and  heavy  truck-trailer  combinations,  and  some  buses.  The 
rehabilitated road will generate significant traffic serving local traffic needs, the rapidly growing 
tourism centered around Siem Reap, and subregional trade between Cambodia and Thailand.

HIV/AIDS Program 

42. 
HIV/AIDS is spreading in Cambodia. HIV was first detected in Cambodia in 1991 and the 
first AIDS case diagnosed in 1993. In less than a decade, the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Cambodia 
became one of the most serious and fastest rising in the region. The main mode of transmission 
is currently through heterosexual sex. In 2000, HIV rates among sex workers ranged from 7.7% 
to  58%  across  provinces  with  an  average  of  31%  among  direct  commercial  workers  and  16% 
among indirect sex workers. Sexually transmitted infection (STI) care and related interventions, 
combined  with  100%  condom  use  promotion  and  outreach  for  population  groups  in  high-risk 
situations, have been identified as key components of HIV prevention in the National Strategy 
for  Prevention  and  Care  of  HIV/AIDS  and  STIs  for  2001–2005.  This  strategy  has  been 
implemented  in  the  pilot  province  of  Kampong  Cham.  Banteay  Meanchey  is  one  of  five  new 
target provinces for the “Triangle of HIV Prevention” to be strengthened by the end of 2004. A 
2000 survey indicated that approximately 2.8% of all Cambodians were then infected with HIV.

A. 

Benefits 

63. 
The  Project  will  promote  economic  growth  from  increased:  agricultural  production; 
tourism around the many historic temples throughout the project area; national and subregional 
trade; and local employment creation, which will help combat widespread poverty, especially in 
the  rural  areas.  The  Project  will  also  provide  efficient  all-weather  access  to  the  rural  areas  in 
three  provinces  in  northwestern  Cambodia;  to  the  provincial  and  commercial  centers  at  Siem 
Reap,  Sisophon,  and  Samrong;  and  to  Poipet,  Cambodia’s  primary  border  crossing  point  with 
Thailand.  By  reducing  road  transport  cost  and  improving  access  reliability,  the  Project  will 
generate  substantial  direct  economic  benefits  from  future  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs, 
logistics,  and  road  maintenance.  It  will  also  relieve  the  isolation  of  remote  rural  areas  by 
reducing  travel  cost  and  time,  and  by  eliminating  seasonal  disruption  of  traffic  during  the  wet 
season,  thus  enabling  continuous  trade  and  economic  exchange  and  undisrupted  access  to 
schools,9  health  services,10  and  other  services  in  rural  areas.  Finally,  the  Project  will  enhance 
the impact of the Northwestern Rural Development Project by providing crucial interconnection 
of rural road networks without which “. . . the country will remain fragmented and the rural roads 
will, at best, lead to small provincial towns, isolating the poor population and limiting the benefits 
of  trade  available  to  them.”11  The  main  benefits  of  the  Project  are  directly  related  to  traffic, 
including (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, (ii) savings in vehicle and passenger time costs, 
and  (iii) benefits  from  traffic  generated  by  the  reduction  in  transport  costs.  Additional  benefits 
derived  from  generated  traffic  include  (iv) producer  surplus  benefits,  (v) additional  income 
engendered by tourism, (vi) additional income from the increased agricultural activity stemming 
from the rehabilitation of the road, and (vii) social benefits arising from better access to schools, 
medical  facilities,  and  other  social  services.  Derived  subregional  benefits  that  have  not  been 
quantified are long term, associated with the road’s contribution to increased integration of the 
economies of Thailand, Cambodia, and Viet Nam that, eventually, will enable the establishment 
of new and more efficient trading and transport patterns in the subregion. The economic internal 
rate of return (EIRR) is 30.7%. The economic analysis is in Supplementary Appendix E.

Environmental Impacts 

65. 
The  Tonle  Sap  is  the  largest  freshwater  lake  in  Southeast  Asia.  It  covers  an  area  of 
approximately  250,000 ha  in  the  dry  season,  and  extends  to  1,000,000  ha  during  the  wet 
season.  NR6  crosses  a  floodplain  that  is  linked  to  the  upper  part  of  the  Tonle  Sap.  Both  the 
floodplain and the Tonle Sap are essential and linked components of the fisheries of the area. 
The huge wetland system with its habitat diversity supports one of the most productive fisheries 
in Asia. The road linking Siem Reap and Poipet is situated at about 10 m above sea level on a 
large  area  of  the  central  plain  that  surrounds  Tonle  Sap.  The  plain  rises  imperceptibly  at  a 
gradient  of  about  0.03  %  until  it  encounters  the  lower  slopes  of  the  Chuor  Phnum  Dangrek 
range that forms the divide between Cambodia and Thailand. The level of the Tonle Sap varies 
seasonally between 1.1 m and 10.0 m. As the road skirts the flood area, it is within the influence 
area, but is recognized as being in an area of least impact and hence generally environmentally 
benign. 
 
66.  Major  potential  environmental  impacts  are  (i) impacts  on  drainage;  (ii) impacts  on 
fishery;  (iii) noise  and  dust;  (iv) mismanagement  of  construction  materials  and  sites;  and 
(v) health and safety. Mitigation measures have been identified and can be implemented without 
difficulty.  The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE),  together  with  an  appropriately  designed 
environmental management plan and monitoring programs, is considered sufficient to meet the 
environmental impact assessment requirements of the Project. The summary IEE is presented 
in Appendix 15. The full IEE is in Supplementary Appendix F. The Project will be implemented in 
accordance with ADB’s Environmental Guidelines for Infrastructure Projects.

The  road  network  in  Cambodia  covers  about  35,500  kilometers  (km),  including 
1. 
approximately 4,000 km of national roads, 3,500 km of provincial roads, and 28,000 km of rural 
and  strategic  roads.  The  roads  have  a  significant  number  of  bridges,  about  4,000  on  the 
national  roads  alone.  The  primary  roads  consists  of  National  Roads  1-9,  which  are  national 
highways that  extend from Phnom Penh to provincial capitals and the main access points to the 
country.  Lesser  national  roads  with  2-digit  numbers  are  provincial  highways  that  connect  the 
provincial capitals and connect to minor border crossings and important domestic centers. The 
secondary (provincial roads) and tertiary (rural and strategic roads) serve local transport needs. 
The  road  network  was  mostly  built  before  1960.  The  general  design  standards  thus  cater  to 
lighter  traffic  than  current  loads,  with  many  existing  bridges  designed  for  gross  vehicle  road 
weights  of  10  tons,  well  below  the  current  standard  of  up  to  30  tons.  Bridges  have  often 
collapsed  due  to  overloading.  Most  of  the  road  network  is  dilapidated  and  large  parts  of  the 
country are effectively isolated during the wet season. Most bridges are seriously damaged or 
failed.  The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Transport  (MPWT)  considers  that  at  least  half  of  the 
primary  road  network  and  nearly  all  the  secondary  and  tertiary  roads  are  in  need  of  urgent 
repair, rehabilitation, or reconstruction. Road condition surveys in 2002 confirm that 28% of the 
network is in good or fair condition, 35% in poor condition, 28% in bad condition, and 6% under 
reconstruction or rehabilitation. 
 
2. 
The  unrehabilitated  sections  of  the  road  network  are  characterized  by  cracks,  ruts, 
potholes, edge failures, and pavement failures. The Government recognizes that the poor state

emphasizes  the  urgency  of  reestablishing  the  country’s  transport  infrastructure.  The  ongoing

national  roads  by  the  year  2003,  thus  ensuring  that  approximately  44%  of  the  national  road

2003  has  been  estimated  at  approximately  $550.0 million  equivalent,  of  which  ADB  has 
financed  approximately  $230.0 million  equivalent.  Currently,

A significant concern in Cambodia is the overloading of trucks, which leads to premature 
deterioration  of  road  pavements  and  threatens  the  stability  of  the  many  bridges  designed  for 
light  traffic.  The  legal  axle  load  in  Cambodia  is  10  tons.  There  is  evidence  that  some  trucks, 
particularly those carrying cement, take on as much as 60 tons over a truck-trailer combination. 
A  survey  carried  out  in  1997  identified  an  average  axle  weight  of  10  tons  with  maximum  axle 
weights of up to 16 tons. Enforcement of axle load limits in Cambodia is weak, and it is essential 
to formulate an effective axle load control program to lead to greatly extended pavement life and 
lower  bridge-maintenance  costs.  This  is  particularly  important  for  bridges,  which  constitute  a 
very large part of the network, as the passage of an exceptionally heavy vehicle could damage 
the structure irreparably. 
 
6. 
Subdecree 744, Maximum Load Limit of Transport Vehicles Using the Road Network in 
Cambodia, was approved by the Government on 3 September 1999. The Subdecree details the 
load limits and sets penalties for overloading. Such penalties should reflect actual damage and 
discourage  overloading.  Pavement  design  is  based  on  the  fact  that  vehicle  damage  to  a  road 
depends  entirely  on  the  axle  load  of  those  vehicles.  The  penalties  listed  in  the  Subdecree 
increase  only  linearly  with  increasing  loads,  but  damage  to  the  road  in  reality  increases 
exponentially as the load increases. Small increases in axle load above the legal limit of 10 tons 
can result in a severe increase in damage to the road pavement. As far as practicable, penalties 
should reflect the exponential increase in damage.

Road Maintenance Management and Financing 

In  2000  and  2001,  MPWT’s  expenditures  on  the  primary  and  secondary  road  network 
9. 
(the national and provincial roads) averaged approximately $12.5 million per year, of which 20% 
($2.5 million)  were  recurrent  expenditures  for  routine  maintenance,  and  80%  ($10.0 million) 
were  capital  expenditures  for  repair  and  rehabilitation  of  pavements.  Annual  average  external 
agency  funding  added  an  estimated  $60.0 million  for  road  rehabilitation  and  improvement;  the 
Government’s  expenditures  for  counterpart  funding  of  externally  financed  projects  was 
approximately $6.0 million equivalent, making for total maintenance and rehabilitation funding of 
$79.0 million. No new funds are being expended on the construction of new roads. 
 
10. 
The  management  of  a  road  network  must  be  based  on  business  principles,  using 
economic  criteria  to  prioritize  and  schedule  maintenance  works.  An  asset  management 
approach  is  most  appropriate  as  a  long-term  goal  for  maintaining  and  preserving  the  road 
network.  In  Cambodia’s  situation,  this  implies  a  move  from  the  present  crisis-response 
management mode to a network management mode as the core network stabilizes and normal 
periodic  maintenance  works  can  be  scheduled  in  a  cost-effective  manner.  Essential  to  that 
approach  is  the  establishment  of  the  maintenance  management  system  with  its  basic  building 
blocks  that  include  a  road  and  bridge  inventory,  a  system  for  updating  the  inventory  and 
accompanying condition surveys, and application of evaluation tools to prioritize and schedule 
periodic maintenance. An ADB-financed study4 has developed a decentralized approach to road 
condition  monitoring,  and  the  programming  and  management  of  routine  maintenance  that  is 
suitable  for  implementation  by  provincial  public  works  departments.  The  study  initiated 
implementation  of  the  maintenance  management  system  in  three  pilot  provinces,  with  the 
system  now  being  adopted  by  MPWT  for  replication  in  the  remaining  provinces  of  Cambodia. 
The system is based on a relatively straightforward road condition assessment procedure that 
involves  (i) vehicle  operating  speeds  and  travel  time,  (ii) drainage  considerations,  and 
(iii) engineering judgment. 
 
11.

essential  to  ensure  security  of  funding  and  reliable  cash  flow  with  the  attendant  technical  and

allocated  in  the  annual  budget  in  effect  cover  only  periodic  maintenance  and  pavement 
rehabilitation. The investment budget is retained by the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) 
and  disbursed  on  a  project  basis.  When  the  FRMR  was  established  in  2000,  it  required

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 
 
The key contribution of the infrastructure sector is to strengthen linkages between rural and urban areas and between 
different  regions  of  the  country  to  promote  economic  growth  and  development  activities  that  are  geographically 
balanced.  
 
The majority of the poor in Cambodia live in rural areas and base their livelihoods on agricultural activities. Many of 
the poor face food shortages for several months and are vulnerable to external shocks due to reliance on subsistence 
agriculture  and  deprived  access  to  social  services.  Improved  infrastructure  will  lead  to  increased  openness  for 
communities  deprived  of  adequate  access  to  information  and  markets.  This  will  increase  access  to  off-farm 
employment and diversification of risk and vulnerability. Access to markets will reduce vulnerability to food shortages 
and  reliance  on  subsistence  agriculture.  Enhanced  access  will  also  enable  the  Government  and  external  financing 
agencies to provide social services to deprived areas. 
 
B. 
Socioeconomic and Poverty Profile in the Project Area: 
 
The area under the proposed Project includes the provinces of Siem Reap, Banteay Meanchey and Oddar Meanchey 
in Northwestern Cambodia. This area suffers from high incidence of poverty and has received minimal development 
assistance in the past because of war and insecurity. Owing to the security situation at the time of the implementation 
of  the  socioeconomic  surveys,  reliable  poverty  statistics  on  a  comparative  basis  with  the  rest  of  the  country  are 
unavailable and the statistics presented are only indicative. Although some data indicating vulnerability exist for Siem 
Reap and Banteay Meanchey, the data for Oddar Meanchey are either merged with Siem Reap or do not exist. Given 
the  more  developed  areas  around  Siem  Reap,  the  data  do  not  serve  to  adequately  reflect  the  poverty  and 
vulnerability  that  prevails  in  Oddar  Meanchey.  The  lack  of  data  in  this  province  is  in  itself  an  indication  of  lack  of 
access to Government, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and aid agencies. Due to high labor mobility, the data 
for Banteay Meanchey can be regarded as outdated, and vulnerability is likely to be underestimated for that reason. A 
detailed  survey  was  fielded  to  further  investigate  poverty  and  vulnerability  and  likely  impacts  of  increased  access, 
through  a  socioeconomic  survey  and  participatory  focus  group  discussions.  Based  on  survey  data  on  poverty  and 
vulnerability, the proposed classification of the Project is poverty intervention.  
 
Survey  data  suggest  that  poverty  is  widespread  in  the  area  with  severe  problems  of  accessibility  during  the  rainy 
season. The WFP study indicates that no less than 60% of households suffer from food deficiency although there is 
some  scope  here  for  foraging,  hunting,  and  gathering  activities  to  supplement  precarious  livelihoods.  Most 
households find their food stocks depleted within 4 months of harvest. The overall poverty estimates for the project 
area is about 40%. However, there are significant variations, with the areas serviced by better roads displaying the 
lowest poverty level (25%), while NR56 and areas serviced by poor roads have very high poverty levels (over 60%). 
Thus, quite apart from relatively high poverty levels in the project area compared with the national situation, there are 
deep  pockets  of  extensive  poverty,  much  of  which  is  related  to  the  relative  physical  remoteness  and  poor 
infrastructure in the area. Government services, such as health and education, rarely reach the interior and tend to be 
restricted  to  peri-urban  areas.  Insecurity  and  lack  of  access  have  reduced  the  effectiveness  and  outreach  of  NGO 
activities. 
 
The  vulnerability  of  the  population  in  this  area,  and  especially  that  of  the  poor,  is  marked  by  a  number  of  factors. 
These  include  adverse  demographic  and  socioeconomic  conditions  that  include  a  high  dependency  ratio,  illiteracy, 
poor access to drinking water and health facilities, and low school enrolment and attendance in comparison with the 
overall,  national  situation.  Adult  literacy  is  estimated  at  46%  compared  with  a  national  average  of  over  67%.  The 
population with access to safe drinking water and sanitary latrines is estimated at less than 7% and 4%, respectively, 
compared  with  a  national  average  of  29%  and  15%,  and  school  attendance  (5–14  age  group)  is  below  60% 
compared with 66% for the whole country. This is indicative of high opportunity costs of children to attend school and 
the need to engage children in livelihood activities. 
 
Access to credit is severely limited and savings are small, leading to frequent asset-liquidation to meet crises (most 
frequently  caused  by  health  shocks).  Family  spacing  is  nonexistent  and  whatever  reproductive  services  exist  are 
largely  inaccessible  due  to  the  widely  dispersed  nature  of  the  population  and  long  travel  distances/time  needed  to

reach these (especially in Oddar Meanchey).  
 
The  national  data  related  to  women-headed  households  suggest  a  lower  poverty  incidence  compared  with  similar 
male-headed households. This may not be true for the project area where at least one report points to the serious 
disadvantages faced by the former especially when able-bodied male labor is not available. Similarly the incidence of 
disabled persons is high in the area (2.2 per 1000 compared with the national average of 1.5). This is a reflection of 
prolonged  civil  strife  and  the  presence  of  unexploded  ordnance  (UXO)  in  the  area.  Further,  more  recently  settled 
villages tend to be poorer as these are yet to establish more secure livelihood systems.  
 
Indigenous  ethnic  minorities  are  not  found  in  the  immediate  project  area  as  war  and  insecurity  led  them  to  move 
northeast. A few remote villages, beyond the direct influence area, have ethnic minority groups such as the Pnong 
engaged in rice farming and the Cham, found around Tonle Sap, engaged in fishing. They are not considered to be 
disadvantaged in comparison to ethnic Khmers.  
 
Livelihood security is a chief concern of the poorest 40%. They are primarily subsistence farmers growing one (rain-
fed)  crop  a  year,  often  of  low  quality  or  yields  (which  are  significantly  lower  than  those  in  similar  agro-ecological 
areas). Irrigation is scarce and unreliable.  
 
Migration 
 
Due  to  its  proximity  to  Thailand,  the  area  is  prone  to  labor  mobility,  both  inward  and  outward.  A  large  number  of 
people  migrate  to  the  towns  and  to  Thailand  in  search  of  work,  usually  illegally.  They  migrate  for  mainly  economic 
reasons, in response to wage differentials between Thailand and Cambodia, food shortages and underemployment. 
Most  of  the  migrants  are  poor  or  very  poor  with  inadequate  landholdings.  Short-term  migration  takes  place  in 
response  to  underemployment  during  off-peak  agricultural  seasons  and  serves  as  a  coping  mechanism  for  food 
insecurity. The majority are women who work just across the border. Long-term migrants, the majority of whom are 
men, belong to households with sufficient assets to finance their trips. They travel deep into Thailand and engage in 
unskilled  employment  activities  such  as  construction  work,  manufacturing  and  food  processing  activities.  While 
migration  is  risky  and  can  cause  problems  for  those  left  behind,  many  report  positive  outcomes  and  migration  is 
judged to be good for the development of skills.  
 
Migration to the area has occurred in response to internal displacement, prevailing poverty and landlessness in other 
areas, and the search for hope of better opportunities. This is evident in the area around Poipet, which has seen a 
rapid increase in the size of its population, from 30,000 in 2000 to over 100,000 in 2002. The town has grown largely 
in response to the casinos established on the Cambodian side. This has led to a rapid increase in urban poverty. A 
similar  trend  is  emerging  in  the  border  town  of  O’smach  in  Oddar  Meanchey.  Newly  settled  households  tend  to  be 
more vulnerable, lack social cohesion, and are more likely to live in poverty than older and more established settlers. 
 
HIV/STI 

The Cambodian Demographic Health Survey, 2000 reveals that Banteay Meanchey is one of the provinces with the 
lowest level of awareness of AIDS, with 79% of respondents aware of HIV/AIDS compared with the national average 
of 95% awareness. A 2000 HIV surveillance testing in Banteay Meanchey found the following rates of HIV positive 
people in the groups tested: 7.3% of police, 37.3% of direct commercial sex workers, 13.3% of indirect sex workers, 
and 4% of pregnant women attending antenatal clinics. While this is a decrease from previous years, it is still very 
high. The merged data for Siem Reap/Oddar Meanchey show that awareness is in line with the national average. But 
for Oddar Meanchey this is likely to be a significant overestimation. All three provinces rank low in terms of women’s 
knowledge of HIV/STD prevention. 

 

Expected Impacts on Poverty and Vulnerability  

The impacts on the poor in the project area would largely depend on how national roads 6 and 5 are linked to the 
local  road  network.  To  maximize  the  impacts,  the  proposed  Project  includes  road  improvements  and  all-weather 
accessibility along national roads 68 and 56, which form a loop in Oddar Meanchey. The loop will feed directly into 
the ADB-financed Northwestern Rural Development Project1 (NRDP) and enhance the joint poverty impacts of both 
national  roads  6  and  5  under  the  proposed  Project  and  the  impacts  identified  under  NRDP.  Thus,  the  proposed 
Project intends to provide an integrated approach linking feeder roads (under NRDP) with provincial roads and the 
national roads. This would increase the poverty reduction impacts of both the NRDP and the proposed developments 
on national roads 6 and 5.

Recent  studies  of  the  impact  of  feeder  roads  show  that  the  competitiveness  of  transport  facilities  is  an  important 
factor for the impacts on poverty reduction. This would show the impacts of savings in vehicle operating costs on the 
poor. Within a competitive environment reduced costs would be transferred to the consumers of transport facilities. 
Transport services in Cambodia tend to be highly competitive and therefore the main beneficiaries would be the users 
of such facilities.  
 
Key  impacts  include  higher  producer  prices  and  a  wider  span  of  marketing  options  for  agricultural  produce  and 
increased opportunity for trade to reduce food shortages. Access to national roads 6 and 5, a main trade route with 
growing  markets,  will  further  increase  farmers’  abilities  to  reach  a  variety  of  markets.  All-weather  access  along  the 
loop  and  into  the  target  villages  of  NRDP  will  reduce  the  costs  of  accessing  social  services  like  health  care  and 
education.  The  ability  of  outreach  into  Oddar  Meanchey  and  effectiveness  of  government  and  other  agencies  in 
providing services will significantly improve as both feeder roads and main roads are improved. Only a few NGOs, 
WFP, and de-mining companies are active in the area around the loop. They are mainly engaged in emergency relief 
and  food  for  work  programs.  Most  of  their  project  beneficiaries  are  disabled,  war  widows,  or  displaced  people 
belonging  to  the  poor  or  very  poor.  Increased  access  to  these  areas  will  facilitate  a  more  effective  outreach  for 
organizations engaged in direct poverty reduction efforts. 
 
The  most  immediate  impact  of  the  proposed  Project  includes  employment  opportunities  during  road  construction. 
Road construction work tends to be self-targeting of the poor. Although this impact is deemed as short run, the design 
of  local  maintenance  contracts  under  the  Project  will  act  to  promote  longer-term  wage  and  employment  impacts. 
Together with increased access to a wider range of employment activities labor-intensive road construction and local 
maintenance contracts provide off-farm employment opportunities that are key to poverty reduction. This is especially 
important  for  the  landless  and  for  those  with  inadequate  land  resources.  International  Labour  Organization  (ILO) 
studies show that nearly 47% of road workers are women. Local employment opportunities will reduce the need for 
migration to Thailand, and thus reduce vulnerability for those left behind. Thus, by incorporating local labor contracts 
in the design, the Project will act to reduce the rate of increase in labor migration. 
 
Social Risks 
 
One of the major objectives of the proposed Project is to enhance economic integration, increase mobility and intra- 
and cross-border trade. While labor mobility is already high, mobility can be expected to increase both to and from 
this  area.  Given  the  rather  high  incidence  of  HIV/AIDS  in  Banteay  Meanchey  and  low  awareness  together  with  an 
expected increase of truck-drivers going through the area, there is a risk of further spread of HIV/AIDS to and from 
the project area. In order to reduce this risk, a participatory approach to raising HIV/AIDS awareness will be followed. 
This  will  be  based  on  best  practices  developed  under  TA  5881-REG:  Preventing  HIV/AIDS  Among  Mobile 
Populations in the Greater Mekong Subregion. 
 
Labor-Based Appropriate Technologies 
 
There  are  a  number  of  poverty-oriented  gaps  in  the  current  road  program.  First,  there  is  a  need  to  connect  the 
primary  and  the  rural  roads  with  secondary  roads.  Second,  there  is  a  need  to  develop  more  opportunities  for  and 
capacity  of  domestic  private  contractors  who  are  capable  and  equipped  to  take  on  construction  and  maintenance 
work on the national and provincial roads. Third, more research needs to be done on road technologies best suited to 
Cambodia  in  terms  of  directly  and  indirectly  achieving  poverty  reduction  goals,  including  compilation  and  review  of 
experiences  from  other  countries.  Finally,  there  is  a  need  for  greater  capacity  for  the  training  of  engineers,  public 
sector  officials,  and  private  sector  contractors  and  consultants  in  road  technologies  and  management.  A  project 
concept,  Mainstreaming  Poverty  Reducing  Approaches  into  the  National  Road  Network,  has  been  developed  for 
grant  financing  under  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  to  reduce  poverty  by  refining  pro-poor  appropriate 
technological  solutions  recently  developed  in  Cambodia,  and  mainstreaming  them  into  the  road  programs  of  the 
Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Transport,  and  the  Ministry  of  Rural  Development.  The  Project  will  work  toward 
maximizing  the  input  of  local  entrepreneurs,  materials,  labor,  and  ingenuity.  Thus,  there  is  expected  to  be  both  an 
immediate  direct  effect  on  income  through  employment  and  a  long-term  direct  effect  through  the  provision  of  cost-
effective tools for the management of the road network.

Description of the Environment 

1. 

Physical Resources 

3. 
The  road  linking  Siem  Reap  and  Poipet  is  situated  at  about  10  meters  (m)  above  sea 
level (asl) on a large area of the central plain that surrounds the Tonle Sap and continues to the 
Mekong river system. Protruding from the plain are a few scattered outcrops of small sandstone 
hills  that  may  rise  to  about  100  m  asl  above  the  plain.  Otherwise,  the  plain  is  flat  and 
featureless. From the Tonle Sap the plain rises imperceptibly at a gradient of about 0.03% until 
it  encounters  the  lower  slopes  of  the  Chuor  Phnum  Dangrek  range  that  forms  the  divide 
between Cambodia and Thailand. The range rises to heights of about 400 m asl. 
 
4. 
 The  climate  of  the  area  is  characterized  by  a  distinct  wet  and  dry  season.  The 
southwest  monsoon  starts  in  May  and  ends  in  October  while  from  November  to  April  the  dry 
northeast  monsoon  occurs.  Temperatures  are  high  throughout  the  year  with  a  daytime 
maximum of nearly 35 degrees Centigrade occurring in April just prior to the rainy season. With 
increased  cloud  cover  from  the  southwest  monsoon,  daytime  temperatures  decrease  while  a 
slight seasonal effect lowers the temperature to 30 degrees Centigrade in December. Average 
rainfall is 1,400–1,500 mm at Siem Reap with about 80% of the rainfall in the wet season. 
 
5. 
The  hydrology  of  the  area  is  dominated  by  three  systems,  namely  (i) the  hydrological 
conditions  of  the  upper  catchment  areas  of  the  Chuor  Phnum  Dangrek,  (ii) locally  derived 
drainage  that  originates  from  the  main  water  courses  and  enters  the  Tonle  Sap,  and  (iii) the 
operation of the Tonle Sap itself. In normal years, the Tonle Sap operates within the levels of 
1.1 m asl and 10.0 m asl. As the road is set about 10.0 m asl, parts of the road that cross the 
plain at or below this level are influenced. 
 

2. 

Ecological Resources 

6. 
The  dominant  land  cover  along  the  road  between  Siem  Reap  and  Poipet  is  a  mix  of 
paddy  fields  and  extensive  grazing.  Surrounding  and  within  some  of  the  paddy  areas  sugar 
palms are seen. From Sisophon to Poipet, shrub and low woody vegetation are dominant where 
they are not cleared for paddy areas.

Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures

Drainage 

12. 
The project area between Siem Reap and Sisophon is sometimes inundated in the wet 
season. The raising of an embankment between Siem Reap and Sisophon to a flood-free height 
will cause additional runoff to be held behind the embankment that will require an engineering 
solution  in  terms  of  additional  cross-flow  discharge  capacity  to  be  incorporated  within  the 
embankment.  This  may  be  achieved  by  widening  the  existing  bridges  and  culverts  or 
constructing additional cross-drainage through the road embankment. 
 
The  provision  of  additional  cross-drainage  will  relieve  water  height  that  may  build  up 
13. 
against the embankment and if correctly designed, additional cross-drainage may maintain the 
flood  level  at  the  same  height  on  both  sides  of  the  embankment.  In  areas  where  rice  is 
cultivated,  improved  drainage  gives  landholders  better  access  to  their  paddy  fields  and 
increased  rice  production.  In  order  to  facilitate  drainage  of  floodwater,  additional  culverts  are 
necessary  for  cross-drainage.  In  the  project  area,  erosion  may  not  be  significant  due  to  the 
hydrology  in  the  area.  However,  good  construction  practices  will  be  implemented  to  avoid 
unnecessary sedimentation and water pollution.

Fisheries 

14.  Most  of  the  fish  species  that  are  found  in  and  around  the  Tonle  Sap  do  not  have
